13	Through my experience as an undergraduate Engineering student in my final year, I have found that the university environment is actually uninspiring. After three years, you come to the realization that everyone is just passing by, as if they are simply going through the motions, with the only aim being to become another statistic for the department they are in. Worst of all, it seems like no one even notices. For example, with my final year project, I was highly motivated and enjoyed it immensely, but it seemed that everyone else wanted it to end quickly - no passion for what they had created. Therefore, it seems that universities are not here to serve humanity, but instead is just a machine for producing figures for the corporate world.
14	Bad Company 2 is boring as it is difficult to kill people, the controls are awkward with vehicles, the maps are too big, and people hate the size and scope of the Battlefield maps.  Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, however, has intense gameplay due to its unpredictability. You never know what's around the corner or if an enemy is waiting to ambush you with a sniper rifle or a thrown grenade. Additionally, with fewer magazines and skills to develop, you have to be more strategic in your approach in MW2. Weapons are also more realistic, save for the AT4 which is not a guided munition. Overall, Battlefield is boring in comparison to MW2 due to its lack of intensity and unpredictability.
15	I always hear people talking about how the death penalty needs to be enforced more often. I, personally, am undecided on my opinion on the death penalty, but in my mind, the death penalty is used primarily as a societal form of retaliation (much the way that putting someone's head on a pike was used in the past). If this is true, should we as a society not want as many as possible to see what happens to people when they are sentenced to death? At the very least, it will inform the public about what execution in the United States is actually like (this may, in turn, change the beliefs that someone holds on the death penalty).
16	You can't export democracy by force as it takes the will of the people to form such a government.  Muslim countries do not have the same Enlightenment background that we had in the nascent United States when forming a secular constitutional republic.  Islam demands that church and state be united, with the rule of law coming from the Quran.  Despite the attempts of some right-wing conservative religious types, in America we have a wall of separation between religion and the government, allowing citizens to follow the dictates of their own conscience.  Islam needs to go through its own Enlightenment before any type of western democracy will have a chance to succeed.  Until then, we can only keep (weak) control by military force, which creates its own blowback as we now see in the Middle East.

Lastly, why the fuck would you use a shared toilet without looking before using it while expecting male users to do the looking for both themselves and the women?   Putting the seat up after use is a reasonable request as it minimizes any discomfort the next user may experience. Furthermore, it is unfair to expect men to constantly put the seat up after use as it cancels out the expectation that men should put the seat down after use.

22	The argument presented is that the Stormcloaks being portrayed as the exclusive bad guys of the Civil War in Skyrim makes the quest line and story weaker. The main points presented to support this argument are that the Stormcloaks are racist, abusive, and use dark magic, making them the “villains” by modern morales. Additionally, Ulfric's use of the Thu'um to kill the High King further enforces the argument that the Stormcloaks are the antagonists.   To CMV, it could be argued that the Stormcloaks being the only bad guys in the civil war is an oversimplification, and that there is more complexity to the situation. Additionally, it could be argued that the Stormcloaks have their own motivations and perspectives which complicate the situation. Furthermore, it could be argued that the narrative of the Civil War in Skyrim makes clear the moral and ethical grey areas of the conflict, and portrays the Stormcloaks, and Ulfric in particular, as not being as black and white as they initially seem.

column1: 96	Today a cat passed on to a busy road. It stood there and was partially injured
column2: then killed by other cars passing over it.  My sister cried out emotionally watching this poor animal suffer. I
column3: however
column4: did not feel anything. Watching a animal die will always be unpleasant
column5: but it is not something that one should show emotion for. The animal itself was feral
column6: it had no owners to care for it. We also show no connection to the animal; our relationship is like myself viewing a tree in another field. I am a wage earner
column7: I have no duty of care to an animal running across the road.   It makes sense to feel nothing for the animal as it is another of the many organisms which die and do not have a direct effect on our lives.
